did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract:
Papers include correspondence, deeds and agreements, personal and business accounts, petitions, drafts of speeches, and resolutions, mainly concerning local politics and patronage, the Anti-Masonic Party, abolitionist agitation, temperance, the use of convict labor, pensions for veterans of the American Revolution and the War of 1812, opposition to the Bank of the United States, and land speculation in Michigan, Wisconsin, and other parts of the Midwest; also, correspondence and legal and financial papers pertaining to a case involving the Geneva & Rushville Plank Road Company (1849-50) and other lawsuits, to the settlement of the estates of the Brackett and James families, Orpha Gates, Oren Green, John Lee, Nathan Pratt, and Royal Stearns, and to Loomis's interest in Geneva College (1827-38), now Hobart College; also, a deed (1813) for land in the
town of Gorham from Ann Ellice and her children; bills and tuition and board receipts (1832-34) from Genesee Wesleyan Seminary, Lima, Livingston County, New York, for Loomis's daughter, Amanda; thirty-three Civil War letters (162-64) written from various camps by his son, Charles, Morris O'Connell, Fayette Green, and other area men serving in the Union Army. Other correspondents include the Ontario County Antislavery Society, Skaneateles Antislavery Society, William Ansley, Samuel Colt, William T. Crittenden, Richard Gilbert, James Loomis, Congressman Meredith Mallory, and Augustus Torrey.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Merchant; postmaster, Rushville, New York; Associate Judge of Ontario County; New York State Senator, 1835-38.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p:
Papers include correspondence, deeds and agreements, personal and business accounts, petitions, drafts of speeches, and resolutions, mainly concerning local politics and patronage, the Anti-Masonic Party, abolitionist agitation, temperance, the use of convict labor, pensions for veterans of the American Revolution and the War of 1812, opposition to the Bank of the United States, and land speculation in Michigan, Wisconsin, and other parts of the Midwest; also, correspondence and legal and financial papers pertaining to a case involving the Geneva & Rushville Plank Road Company (1849-50) and other lawsuits, to the settlement of the estates of the Brackett and James families, Orpha Gates, Oren Green, John Lee, Nathan Pratt, and Royal Stearns, and to Loomis's interest in Geneva College (1827-38), now Hobart College; also, a deed (1813) for land in the town of Gorham from Ann
Ellice and her children; bills and tuition and board receipts (1832-34) from Genesee Wesleyan Seminary, Lima, Livingston County, New York, for Loomis's daughter, Amanda; thirty-three Civil War letters (162-64) written from various camps by his son, Charles, Morris O'Connell, Fayette Green, and other area men serving in the Union Army. Other correspondents include the Ontario County Antislavery Society, Skaneateles Antislavery Society, William Ansley, Samuel Colt, William T. Crittenden, Richard Gilbert, James Loomis, Congressman Meredith Mallory, and Augustus Torrey.

scopecontent.p: "Some are mortgaging there [sic] farms and paying 25 & 30 percent for to get Money to go to California People are intoxicated an [sic] destracted [?] here in there [sic] imagination."

Series XV. Soldiers' Letters Civil War
Chester Loomis to Lieut. J. H. Brough

scopecontent.p: Advice that Maurice O'Connell execute an allotment certificate for the support of his three children.

did.unittitle: (overleaf) Lieut. J. H. Brough to Chester Loomis" (Camp Swift, Geneva)

scopecontent.p: Notification of O'Connell's signing an allotment of $10.00 per month for support of children also that bounty was sent home by Lyman Loomis.
Location of camp, 2 miles west of Harper's Ferry. Uncertain when fight will star surrounded on all sides. Men are in good health} the scarcity of money; desire that children be cared for.

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Loomis (Camp Douglas, Chicago)

scopecontent.p: Report of surrender; stolen clothing -and goods; journey to Chicago and encampment conditions there; request for money; desire that children be cared for.
Request that Chest inquire whether or not Mr. Flinn has the money and booty which Tyler sent him.

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (Camp Douglas, Chicago)

scopecontent.p: Request for $25.00 to replace money and clothing which was stolen at surrender of Harper's Ferry; will repay $26.00 when paid.

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Loomis (Camp Douglas, Chicago)

scopecontent.p: Request for money; quarters are very bad and the cold weather is coming. Report that he has received no answer to his previous letters.

did.unittitle: M. O'Connell to Chester Loomis (Camp Douglas, Chicago)

scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of CL's letter, very little prospect of coming home soon; concern of report by guardian of children, Mrs. Scott, of children's behavior; request that CL check them to see if the children should be taken to another place.

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (Camp Douglas, Chicago)

scopecontent.p: Request for $15.00; rumor that camp will move to New York State from Chicago; conditions of camp very poor; average of four deaths a day and many men in hospital; delight of seeing Rev.Hudson, CL's pastor.

Acknowledgement of CL's letter and $2.00; report that Burnside and his whole force had to retreat loss of 12,000 men; signs of fight coming insufficient supply of men; bad conditions of camp; impatient to finish war; personal thoughts of the war and the benefits being: a soldier; no money.

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Loomis (Union Mills, Va.)

scopecontent.p: Received pay finally; request that CL see that children are provided for; many deaths in regiment; rumor that they will move but new location unknown; present location, Onion Mills.
Allotment pay able to CL $27.00 and other financial matters; death of two Rushville boys.
Request for $10.00 return because wallet was stolen from camp.
Report of moving to Centerville; possibility of fight soon; Condition of regimen desire to come home, but not without obtaining union of States lack of money.
Lack of money; unable send money for children; request for stamps; possibility of moving camp again

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (Centerville, Va.)

scopecontent.p: Request for $5.00; weather is good.

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (Centerville, Va.)

scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of CL's letter; rumor that Bee has "flanked" Hocker and made him retreat; men are losing faith in Hocker; optimistic viewpoint even though conditions are bad; expecting attack by Stewart's Cavalry. *(Hooker)

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Loomis (Centerville, Va.)

scopecontent.p: Payment of allotment; praise for Grant; request for CL's opinion of the war.

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (Centerville, Va. )

scopecontent.p: Check was enclosed for $25.00; boys in good health; successes of troops.

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Loomis (Centerville, Va. )

scopecontent.p: 30,000 troops joined them at Centerville; Lee is on the move and are our men;" states that he would spend his time and over before He would settle with the South; request for $5.00 to use of Mar..

did.unittitle: Blue slip giving statement of account of Fayette Greene, soldier

scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of CL' letter and $5.00; Mar. from Centerville to Gettysburg; many men lost at battle in Gettysburg; rebs lost more men. Condition of soldiers following battle; spirits high; hopes he will be home soon, but not until the rebs are "cut up to pieces;" Brought is wounded.

Notice of mistake made by check payable to Judge Loomis instead of Chester Looms; says that if there is any trouble about it "send it to the Treasury of the U.S. and state the circumstances." Report that "rebs" have crossed the Potomac River; readiness; for battle; confidence that war will be over soon.

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Locals (near Warrenton Junction)

scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of CL's latter; opinion that those boys who waited for the draft right up until the last minute do not make very good soldiers; rumor that his f friend , John, wounded at Gettysburg, had died, because his leg was amputated and he died after the operation.

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Loomis (Rapidan River)

scopecontent.p: Scarcity of money; clothes lost or stolen often; thank you for the letter to Colonel Bull, but there is "no such thing' as a furlough in the array of the Potomac; rebs are on the other side of the river; tell children to be good.
Possibility of renewal of fight; request that CL write to James Bull, his colonel, to request a furlough so that he can come home and take care of the situations there with the children.

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (Rapidan River)

scopecontent.p: Check was enclosed ($30,00); request that CL put it on interest.

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (Warrenton, Va.)

scopecontent.p: Did not receive answer to last letter acknowledging $20.00; request for $2.00's worth of stamps; corps won two "brilliant victories."

did.unittitle: Fayette Greene to Chester Loomis (near Brandy Station, Va. )

scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of CL's letter; enclosed check for $20.00 to be put on interest; brilliant victory after crossing the river; too many Copperheads; praise for North's response for the war as indicated by the last election.

did.unittitle: Fayette Green to Chester Loomis (near Brandy Station, Va.)

scopecontent.p: -enclosed two-dollar notes; received no losses in their last campaign.

did.unittitle: Fayette Green to Chester Loomis (near Brandy Station, Va. )

scopecontent.p: -returned to old position after Mar.ing all night; Mead retreated after Lee received reinforcement; enclosed money not

did.unittitle: Morris O'Connell to Chester Loomis (near Brandy Station, Va.)

scopecontent.p: Disturbed that his money which he bad sent CL had been stolen; furloughs were being granted, but are stopped again; some chance he might get one in winter; worried about care of children; if he came to Rushville, he would not have a place to stay and would have very little time to do anything about the children.
Request for $2.00's worth of stamps.
Request for knowledge concerning situation of place for his wife to live.
Request for $14.00. (Baltimore)
